posts.cooked:
I wrote a comment on pinned chats feature saying that i considered it as an important feature. However, it was flagged and hidden.
The notification said it was against the community rules. Which rule could it be against?

link_counts.title: iOS Backups / Keeping message history when resetting phone
What is the Trigger for the "awaiting approval" state of a post

posts.cooked:
Karjala:

saying that i considered it as an important feature.

They don’t like users’ input in support of a post as they feel it ‘bumps’ a topic, which is against the rules for some reason. See: FAQ - Signal Community

Instead, you’re invited to click the ““ to show support. Meanwhile, in absence of a meaningful voting system, the topic gets pushed further and further back so, even in the unlikely event a post gets 1000 ‘Likes’, it’s unlikely to be seen again unless someone searches for the post - which is, at best, arduous and ‘fiddly’.

Anyway. “Welcome”

Karjala:

Which rule could it be against?

Specifically, this section:

Rather than posting “+1” or “Agreed”, use the Like button.

This applies to any post that essentially just boils down to “I want this too”, as they add nothing to the discussion and create noise on the forum.

anon94207282:

the topic gets pushed further and further back so, even in the unlikely event a post gets 1000 ‘Likes’, it’s unlikely to be seen again unless someone searches for the post

I’m not sure why you think that is somehow a problem.

Herohtar:

I’m not sure why you think that is somehow a problem.

Because, by that reckoning, once a topic has been created and discussed, no one else can enter the discussion and it gets pushed further down a list. It could be a good idea / topic, but pressing a “” doesn’t do anything, as far as I’m aware?

The Upvoting topic seemed to be a good idea in the end.

link_counts.title: Add upvote system to the forum

posts.cooked: If you mean it is less likely that someone will randomly happen upon the topic since it’s not at the top of the list, then yes, that is true. I’m not sure that is a major negative impact though; the feature request exists and the Signal team will be aware of it. It might get fewer likes, but likes are just a minor indicator, and the Signal team doesn’t prioritize or choose to implement features based solely (or much at all) on the likes.

Herohtar:

but likes are just a minor indicator, and the Signal team doesn’t prioritize or choose to implement features based solely (or much at all) on the likes.

Absolutely. I think that’s clear over the past few months…!

I guess that’s entirely their decision. It’s a pity, though. The Upvoting may have provided some direction of both design and features as well as getting the community involved. Particularly new users who often just come along to “+1”.
Does this forum censor posts ? Where am I ?

Welcome to the forum @Bbx32

To show your support to a feature request please hit that icon in the first post.
Bumping topics doesn’t add anything to the discussion and is against the forum guidelines

Bbx32:

Where am I ?

Please read the guidlines, especially the Keep it Tidy section!

Does it affect the visibility anyhow in the eyes of the developers?

Could it be there is an old topic with 1 million likes that nobody know about?

Karjala:

Could it be there is an old topic with 1 million likes that nobody know about?

The topics on the forum can’t be sorted by likes, but they can be sorted by number of views, and if a topic had 1 million likes it would also have at least that many views. So no, there would not be any “invisible” popular topics.

Ability to block / disallow voice messages

flagged by the community and is temporarily hidden

Why is this post “flagged by the community and is temporarily hidden”? Is this how discussions here work? The majority (of active users here) seems not to like/need this feature, but you can’t deny there are more and more people showing up who want exactly this.

posts.name: Salt
posts.cooked:
Seven-Sails-Raider:

Why is this post “flagged by the community and is temporarily hidden”? Is this how discussions here work?

I’m not entirely sure, but I believe it was considered a “bump” and therefore flagged by community members. This usually happens if people respond to a feature request with just a “me too” and don’t add anything to the discussion.

Seven-Sails-Raider:

Why is this post “flagged by the community and is temporarily hidden”? Is this how discussions here work? The majority (of active users here) seems not to like/need this feature, but you can’t deny there are more and more people showing up who want exactly this.

That’s actually an increasing problem in many discussion platforms. There is one “expected” opinion. If you write you don’t like that, they say, tons of people said that before, you bump the thread, and flag you.
If someone else says, the “expected” opinion is exactly what he likes, although 20 others said that before, this is not considered “bumping”.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
free4eversa:

from 01 JAN 2019 until now Signal didn’t add this old feature !!!

Why is my post considered inappropriate and hidden!!

Your post was flagged as inappropriate because it’s against the community guidelines. Your post simply supports the feature request (i.e. it is a “+1” reply). Instead of posting that you are encouraged to like the first post in the topic (using the button).

Regarding the date that you mention: there are many more topics, discussions, and feature requests created even earlier that Signal users want to be addressed. The Signal team reads this forum, but they prioritize features, bug fixes, etc. themselves and do not generally comment on whether features will be implemented or when.

As such, bumping topics unnecessarily just to show your support for the request is discouraged. However, if you notice an official reply regarding a feature, a related change in Signal’s code, or simply want to discuss the rationale for implementing or not implementing a feature or details of its potential implementation, etc., you are of course welcome to post in the topic.

posts.name: free man
posts.cooked:
Thanks u32i64 for your reply.
I respect and understand all what you said. And yes I did “+1” reply to the first post to support the feature request.
But when I scrolled down the related topics and I was shocked it was too old ( more than two years).
Again thanks for your comment and next time I will be more careful.

posts.name: Dr. Matthias H. Fröhlich
posts.cooked:
Update: I received an automated message that this post was hidden as it had been flagged for moderator attention by the community. As I am pretty new to this community I would really be sorry if I should have violated any community guidelines and would like to apologize for any such behaviour from my side. However, as there is no further explanation in the automated message, I would really be grateful for advice about what part of my below post is not acceptable and for what reason. Many thanks in advance.

From my understanding the discussion in this thread has diverted significantly from the major concern raised in the initial posting.

As I was not aware of this thread when I started to raise similar concerns recently, I like to only refer here to my latest posting at Implementation of Disappearing messages is seriously flawed and needs to be revised and would be grateful for all comments to my considerations outlined there. Many thanks in advance.

link_counts.title: Implementation of Disappearing messages is seriously flawed and needs to be revised

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
DrBigMan:

However, as there is no further explanation in the automated message, I would really be grateful for advice about what part of my below post is not acceptable and for what reason.

The user who flagged the post felt that your post was “bumping a topic just to link and ask for comments on another topic”, and a moderator agreed with that flag.

According to Community Guidelines — Keep It Tidy, it’s generally discouraged to “cross-post the same thing in multiple topics” and “post no-content replies”. I don’t think your post is specifically doing any of those, but it does seem like it doesn’t provide any particular value to the topic you’re posting it in. From the same guidelines:

These are not hard and fast rules, merely aids to the human judgment of our community. Use these guidelines to keep this a clean, well-lighted place for civilized public discourse.

In such a case where there is an existing similar topic, rather than posting in it, it’s probably better to flag the duplicate (even if it’s your own post) for the “something else” reason and describe that it may be a duplicate of an existing topic. Moderators can then move posts if needed (this also applies to the case where a discussion has diverted from the original topic—you can flag the post that you think changed the topic, and moderators will consider whether splitting some posts into another topic would be better).

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: Would like to add that volunteer moderators at this time can not modify the automated responses the forum is giving. I know they lack clarity in some cases. Always feel free to send a friendly short message to a mod asking what happened if it’s not clear to you.

posts.name: Dr. Matthias H. Fröhlich
posts.cooked: Many, many thanks for very helpful explanations - highly appreciated.
